utterances.speaker: AISHAH HASNIE, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Aishah Hasnie. Fifty people are now dead in the New Zealand mosque attacks after police found yet another victim at the crime scenes. The police commissioner says 36 people remain in the hospital, two are in critical condition. Memorials are still growing across the city of Christchurch. Mourners have been paying their respects to the victims. The shooter has been charged with one count of murder, but more charges are expected to follow. Yellow Vest protesters filling the streets of Paris for the 18th straight weekend. Demonstrators set fires across the city and at one point, a mother and child had to be rescued from a burning building. More than a hundred people have been arrested. They have been protesting since last November over policy set by French President, Emmanuel Macron. I am Aishah Hasnie, now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: OCASIO-CORTEZ
utterances.utterance: There is scientific consensus that the lives of children are going to be very difficult, and it does lead, I think, young people to have a legitimate question, you know, should -- is it okay to still have children?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez cautioning millennials about climate change and posing the question whether people should even be having more kids. But the movement reaches much further than D.C. Women in Great Britain refusing to have children until global warming ends.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I can't have a child until I'm absolutely convinced that we are on a seriously, seriously different path.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here to explain, the founder of Birth Strike, Blythe Pepino. Okay, Blythe, what are the risks in your opinion of having a child?

utterances.speaker: BLYTHE PEPINO, FOUNDER, BIRTH STRIKE
utterances.utterance: There aren't any risks to having a child as in giving birth, do you mean or in their future?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If you give birth, which you are refusing to do, but if you get pregnant and give birth, what would be the problem to the world or to your child?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: The problem that we are talking about is that we are afraid for these kids' futures.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How would you be afraid of their future?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: We are afraid for their futures.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But what could happen to the child when they grow up?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Well, what we are looking at in the next few decades, the end of the century is worldwide famine --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Famine.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Mass displacement of people, yes, famine, food shortages across the world as a result of drought in the places where we grow food around the world and how we feed ourselves. We are also looking at mass displacement of people. We are talking five to six billion refugees as a result of climate change within our countries and from around the world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so you think if you have a baby and that baby grows up, they are not going to have anything to eat because climate change will cause massive droughts and food shortages. Do you really believe we are not going to have any food in a couple of years because of climate change?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Not in a couple of years, no, in a few decades to the end of the century.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because for decade people on the left or in the media have been predicting the polar ice caps are going to melt. Remember, Al Gore said they would be melted by now and in the 70s and 80s and 90s, they all said that the earth was going to end and there were going to be -- Manhattan was going to be swimming and it was going to sink. These things never happened. What makes you so sure they will if everyone has been wrong before?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to contest with you about the predictions around ecological breakdown. You should just go and look up the science yourself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I have. I mean, the science isn't always right. I mean, the scientists said Y2K --

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: The scientist now have consensus around this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well there was consensus that Y2K was also going to meltdown the entire world.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: The fact that you are arguing this point, do you have a family? Do you you even have a family?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Do you have a wife? Do you have children?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I have children, yes.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Well, are you worried about them? Are you worried about their futures?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I think they are going to be great. I don't think they are going to starve. I think they are going to have plenty to eat.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I look forward to 20 to 30 years' time when that's the case. I really hope that you are right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I think I am right and I just don't believe the science because it's not all there.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Because you have been told not to believe the science by your government. You have been told to not believe the science by your government and now you don't believe it because it suits you because you live in a western country where things aren't happening in your country just yet except for the forest fires that happened in California, except for the other things that are happening as a result of climate change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Blythe, do you remember when all the scientists --

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: So you can just continue to ignore it and continue to not inform your country of what is happening --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you remember when all the scientists thought that the world was the center of the universe? Blythe --

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: But it's coming for us all. That's all I've got to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Blythe, do you remember when all of the scientists said earth was the center of the universe? There was scientific consensus about the geocentric theory? Well, it was wrong. It was wrong. Y2K was wrong.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: You guys are [bleep].

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The germ theory was wrong. There has been a lot of errors in the scientific community. And what happens if you have a kid who solves the climate crisis? You'd be denying the world --

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: We haven't got time. We haven't got time for that. It's over. It's finished.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: maybe your son or daughter could become a Nobel Peace winning scientist and get us all off fossil fuels. Why would you deny the world that chance?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: We haven't got time. Have you not listened to anything that people are telling you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm listening, I'm just not believing.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Well, then, it's a problem with belief then, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, maybe belief, maybe gullibility, but Blythe, I wish you well and do you fly, by the way. Do you drive?

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: I've stopped flying now. I do drive a bit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, because that's going to kill us all, too, so you might want to start walking.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Don't put it on the individual. This is down to corporations and down to governments like yours ignoring telling the truth about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You put it on the individual yourself by not --

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: No, I haven't put it on the individual. I have made a decision because I'm afraid for the child I would bring into the world. This is anti-neonates less movement.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, I have got to go. Blythe, I respect your belief.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: No, you don't, if you respected my belief you would actually go and have a look for yourself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, I looked before the segment, I just disagree. But we can have a difference of opinion.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: I'm sure we can, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very much.

utterances.speaker: PEPINO
utterances.utterance: Bye.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, still ahead. Beto's hands. What's the deal? We are going to debate it and first though, Diamond and Silk on de Blasio, the First Lady, and that crazy college admissions scandal, up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A crazy conspiracy theory about Melania Trump using a body double is back again after these images of the President and the First Lady visiting tornado ravaged Alabama last week were released. Joining me now, Diamond and Silk. Melania has got a body double? Is that what they have now, ladies, come on?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, HOST
utterances.utterance: Listen, this is just pure conspiracy theory. Look, keep in mind now, when they was alleging that Hillary Clinton had a body double, the left was quiet about that. remember, this is salacious gossip. This is what we consider fake news. They want to know why we think they are fake, this is why because they always are conjuring up this kind of foolishness that try to smear our First Lady instead of uplifting her, which is so sad.

utterances.speaker: SILK, HOST, FOX NATION
utterances.utterance: That's right, and keep in mind, the left seems to be full of conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you guys have any body doubles?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: No. ain't nobody be like Diamond. No, no. There will never be another one of me. That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was a body double for David Schwimmer one time on "Friends." But I gained a little weight and they kicked me off.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, now, the next topic I want to talk to you guys about that is Bill de Blasio, meatless Mondays. He doesn't want students eating any meat on Monday because of global warming. Listen to this guy.

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.utterance: This is important on so many levels, but I've got to say, if you're thinking about our kids individually, we want them to be as healthy as they can be and we want them to learn as well as they can learn and meatless Mondays will help. It will create more balance in their lives. We are talking about our climate, the existential threat of global warming. This is something we do that's another contribution to addressing global warming, striking more of a balance in our whole society.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So kids don't have tacos on Monday and the Earth's temperature is going to drop? Ladies, do you guys buy that or not?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Okay, first of all, I get tired of them talking about this climate change, global warming, we can't help what Mother Nature do. You can put all of these things in place and still Mother Nature would take its course. As far as Meatless Monday, leave our children's lunches alone. Michelle Obama messed with their lunches and the kids wouldn't eat it. Leave it alone. And we are not concerned about Meatless Monday. We are concerned about that $850 million that was lost under his wife? What happened to the $850 million? That's what we want him to talk about. Not that Meatless Monday. We don't want to know where's the beef? Where's the money?

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Where's the money?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, I am not sure we'll ever find it, but we will keep looking. Also, this college admissions scandal really getting nasty. One of the daughters of, I believe, Lori Loughlin was involved in it. Here is what she said as she was going to school. Listen to this.

utterances.speaker: OLIVIA JADE GIANNULLI, DAUGHTER OF LORI LOUGHLIN
utterances.utterance: And then the whole college thing, yes, I'm going. I'm living in a dorm with a roommate. I do want the experience of like game days and partying. I don't really care about school as you guys all know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So they greased some administrator to get her into school and she doesn't even want to be in school. She just wants to party.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: This is what's -- okay, self-entitlement. When children are raised to have a sense of entitlement, like you're supposed to do certain things for me, this is what you create that. You created that. When you don't teach your kids to work hard, this is what you create. But I blame the parents for scamming their way to the top and kicking everybody in the face at the bottom is so sad. It's disrespectful and it's embarrassing. I'm embarrassed for them and people keep saying white privilege, no, this is about green privilege. If you have the money, you can buy whatever you want, even your own education, even you being smart.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. That's right. Money does solve a lot of problem. All right, ladies, Diamond and Silk who cannot have enough money because the "Chit-Chat Tour" is blowing up. We'll see you guys next week. All right, next, "Who is Right and Who is Wrong" with Abby and Carley. Coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We've spent a lot of time talking about Beto's crazy hand today, so it begs to ask, is the hand thing good or bad for Beto. Joining me now for today's installment of "Who's Right and Who's Wrong," Fox Nation host Abby Hornacek and Fox News "24/7 Headline" reporter, Carley Shimkus. Carley, when you see Beto the hands going all around, the jazz hands and what not, is it mesmerizing or is it distracting?

utterances.utterance: Are you blind, Carley?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Listen, he has a way of honing in on the one thing that everybody is subconsciously thinking and then it becomes the only thing that people focus on. And there is no greater example of that than low energy Jeb.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: And I really feel like that changed the way people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Low energy Jeb. Look at him here. Look at him here. What is this?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so much so that Jimmy Fallon did a parody of his announcement video and he was doing the crazy hand gestures, too, so it's even made late night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you like the hand thing or not?

utterances.speaker: ABBY HORNACEK, HOST, FOX NATION
utterances.utterance: You know, I have to be really aware of this, too, because I'm tall so I have large hands, and I've talked with my hands before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You could hit someone and knock him out.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I can knock him out or if I put it up by my face, it's the same size as my face, you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, yes, be careful on set, you might knock Carley.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Right, I know. I am okay with it if he's using it. I noticed, I watched the video a few times and he is doing this to every time he lists something, I'm okay with that.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: He's young, he's fresh.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: But when he does it too many times, it's a little distracting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's high energy.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's high energy. That's right. Yes, so, there are probably worse things than his hand gestures.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, we'll find out because we know more about it. All right, so Russell Westbrook, he is on the thunder. He got into it with one of the fans at Utah Jazz game. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so you and your wife.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Abby, you know, you are a basketball person here. What is the standard for behavior as a fan? How far can you go? Because this guy was saying horrible things.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Yes, here is the thing, when you enter a sporting event as an athlete, as a coach, as an owner you know that you are going to get heckled, but I never it's okay as a fan to go for personal attacks. Because it's kind of like social media, right, when you're a troll, there is this invisible barrier between you and Jesse Watters. I can say whatever I want to Jesse Watters because he is not going to come after me. I think fans have this --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you'd be surprised. I know where you work. You're on my floor now here at Fox. I'll hunt you down.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Right, I know. I'll make sure that I use a fake account.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But what about this though, I mean, what about the home court advantage? This is something the other players have to deal with. It's going to get ugly.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: The "you and your wife," I think the wife --

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: His reaction was not okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, now let's talk about St. Patrick's Day. Everyone is going to be celebrating this weekend. Is it an excuse to get sloppy drunk? Yes or no?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Just a one word answer?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't know. Are you even Irish?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't have any Irish in me. I know that some Irish people are offended by St. Patrick's Day because they feel like it promotes a negative stereotype of them drinking too much.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But they like to drink on St. Patrick's Day and you should see New York City around this time of the year. You can't even walk.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I mean, how do you resist green beer? I don't know. But I do think that it's okay that you celebrate. It's a celebration. Everyone should be happy.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think getting offended by St. Patrick's Day is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, and non-Irish people are allowed to partake.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Remember when Max Kellerman like in ESPN said that the Notre Dame Fighting Irish guy was offensive?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The leprechaun?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: The leperchaun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's soft. Okay, I want to read the results of the last thing we did, should men spend a lot of money on gifts for their significant other on Valentine's Day? Yes, 15%; no, 85%.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: But what is the demographic?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Four thousand votes. You guys were right.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Fifteen percent of women answered that poll, 85% --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Abby and Carley, thank you, guys very much.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, "Last Call."

utterances.utterance: Time now for "Last Call." Amazing newly restored footage released this week showing the first detonation of a nuclear bomb. YouTube page Adam Central released a clip from the Trinity Test which took place on July 26th, 1945 in a remote part of the New Mexico desert. It was the world's first nuclear weapons test.
